content.description: Use one of the main starts (the left side start creates a nice testy start) move to the middle of the large ledge.  Climb the small crack that splits the face above the ledge to a blank section, continue up to a deeper larger crack farther up, and continue on up to the top.
Climb outside corner of the main wall (west face), just left of the chimney.  Joins Jims Throne later on up the face.

Start about ten (10) feet left of The Sea of Grunge.  Start way under the overhang, pull the lip and climb up working left towards a horn and a small ledge to stand on, step up onto a blank smooth section work up the left seam to the top. 

  The section above the horn feature is smooth and unprotectable.  A bolt was added just to the left of this section of the climb sometime before Memorial Day 2011.

This chimney is located to the right of Angulation and the extreme left side of Jims Wall.  Climb up the vegetation-infested chimney towards a left leaning chimney (there are some great pocket holds on the left side of the chimney), climb / crawl to the end, and step out of the chimney and continue to the top.
Start five feet left of Gonads.  Traverse under the overhang to the right.  Finish in the corner.
Start just left of the prominent northwest corner, climb it to the top.  Great friction start, moderate climbing beyond!
Same start as Thin Crack, but when you get to the ledge above the big ledge climb the face between Thin Crack and 	Classic Corner.

Start around the right side of the pillar, about five (5) feet left of The Great Chimney start.  Step up in the pocket and climb the excellent finger crack (hint: try laybacking the upper section) up to a fair size outward sloping covey, setup a belay or, continue up the right side of the pillar using the knobs all the way to the top.
At the obvious crack fifteen feet to the right of the chimney. Climb crack to notch and then up small ramp that splits the face.
From the right side of the large ledge, Between Classic Corner and Jims Throne climb straight up to the top.

A classic located between Jims Wall and Pillar #2.  Start climbing in the cave, were it is possible to get a foot on each side of the chimney, stay outside and chimney all the way up to the top. 

  Placing pro up through the chimney is scattered and not real apparent at first, a real challenge to find and place good solid placements from a chimney stance.  Be creative, its all there!
Start at the left facing but right slanting flake 6 feet left of a pine tree.

Use one of the main starts (the middle crack start is a classic) move left to the large ledge (this can be used as a belay station).  Climb up the classic open book corner to a nice belay ledge on the right, either step out left and continue to the top or walk off to the right towards the top of The Great Chimney and The Cave routes. 

  This is a great classic and can be climbed in three (3) real micro-pitches.  An excellent beginner route to start those aspiring new climbers! 

  This area of Jims Wall can become quite crowded at times.  Be patient with fellow climbers learning the ropes!

A dark, sometimes wet route exists back in the deep recesses of The Great Chimney.  Walk about twelve (12) feet back into the cave to a left side ramp work up to a right side cavity, then work your way to the top climbing up ramps, ledges and the final flared chimney moves. 

  This is a good non-roped descent route.  However, the top section (fifteen (15) feet of flared chimney type moves) is a bit scary, so if you are unsure of your abilities go ahead and rope up and enjoy the experience!  Caving gear is optional.  Head lamp is nice!

Start around the right side of the Jims Wall, about five (5) feet left of The Great Chimney start.  Step up in the pocket and start traversing to the right into the cave.  Undercling the large flake working right and up.  Climb till you get stuffed tight up into the chimney.  Enjoy!

From the far left side of the large ledge, climb straight up the face, then angling right across the arched face toward Thin Crack. 

  There are several large lunges to positive holds!

The mother of all the crags at White Rocks.  Its the highest and largest of the three main formations, offering some of the best routes.  You can do all the routes on Jims Wall as a single pitch, or they can be divided into two (2) pitches to get the most out of the climb.  Its overall height is approximately one hundred twenty five (125) vertical feet.
